text: OK.  They may or may not get in. So I suppose we treat them as apologies when we get to that point. So welcome everyone to the meeting. Sorry, we're a couple of minutes late starting. Just need to advise everybody that the meeting is being live streamed. So as usual, if you can indicate movers and seconders and I'll mention them for the resolutions as we go through. Are there any disclosures of members' interest for item three? There are none. So we're on to item four, which is late items. Does anyone have any late items they wish to bring up? No late items. Everyone's waving Andrew, and who was the seconder? Oh, Philip. All those in favour? Aye. Contrary? Carried. So if we go through those minutes, page by page, page one, two, three,  four, five, six, and we would have all got a note this morning from Debbie, I presume, about the Macron. There's some more work being done on that. So, seven, eight, nine, 10, 11,  And 12. So everyone's comfortable with those? I have a mover and seconder. Correct record, Lou, Brown and Marcus. All those in favour? Aye. Contrary? Carried. So we're on to the next item now, which is the dog control agreement. Gary, do you want to make any comment there?
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: So, this is an agreement between Hamilton City Council and ourselves to allow animal control officers to work in each other's area. We were approached by the city. It actually seems like a very sensible proposition to us, but I'll pass to Carl who can perhaps just work through his report and talk about the practicalities of this.
speaker: garrydyet

text: Good morning, everybody. I'll take the report itself as read. As Gary's outlined, the Dog Control Act does allow these agreements between councils to effectively share staff. And when you're bordering another council, there are certainly instances where that can be advantageous.  Hamilton City approached us before the COVID lockdown was a thing, so it was something that was working its way through the pipeline. Hamilton have existing agreements with Waikato District to their north, and they're looking at agreements with Tauranga and other councils in the general area that are of a similar size and nature to them.  Some councils have this ability to enter into an agreement delegated and others don't. So we're in the position where that's not delegated. Hence the report to you today.  The staff basically see this as a common sense approach. We certainly have had instances in the past where a dog has crossed from Hamilton, committed an offence in our district. And in one case, I can remember it literally jumped the fence back into Hamilton. We then had to wait for Hamilton staff to respond from their side in order to resolve that. So some good practicalities there. The actual details we still need to work through. Obviously, a lot of this work's sort of gone on hold in the last couple of weeks.  If there was ever an example of a time where something like this might be useful, I guess this is probably it. So, yeah, happy to take any questions. Greg Morgan Just before I open it up, you just mentioned there in your intro that it was sharing staff.
speaker: karltutty

text: And I understood from the report that there were no sort of staff implication, it was just giving you authority to go in the city and vice versa. Is that the situation or is it actually sharing staff?
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Yeah, sorry, probably a poor choice of words. So it allows us to utilise other people's staff in certain circumstances. So if we needed backup or assistance from Hamilton for a particular matter, then we could call on their staff to assist their staff, as well as the issue of staff being able to cross the boundary in certain situations.
speaker: karltutty

text: OK, all right. Welcome, Elwyn.  Thanks, Carl. OK, open it up to any questions. Liz.
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Hey, Carl, I just I guess this to me seems like the most practical solution I've seen, you know, for your area. And I just think it's just such a great step forward. So I don't have any questions, just fully support. There we go.
speaker: lizstolwyk

text: Sorry, Liz, you're moving it, are you?
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Yeah, I'm happy to move that.
speaker: lizstolwyk

text: Yeah, Liz moved. And Bruce?
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Sorry, I had a question for Carl. With population differences between Waipa and Hamilton City, they've got one pound and we've got two. Could you just elaborate a bit on that?
speaker: brucethomas

text: Yes, so Hamilton does have one centralised Pound. It's probably four times the size of our combined Pound facilities, and it's in a central location in their district. So all of the dogs there in Pound come back to one central location. I guess that's the benefit of having one population area. They just choose to have one facility, and they have their offices and all their support staff based at that same building.
speaker: karltutty

text: Question for Carl Graham here. Sorry, Graham and then Lou.
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Yeah, thank you. Morning Carl, a couple of questions please. Will in fact our dog control officers require warrants?
speaker: grahamewebb

text: My understanding is that if it's not—it may not be a requirement as long as it's covered in the agreement, but we will probably work down ensuring that any staff that we do utilise from Hamilton have some evidence that they are authorised by Waipā to undertake work in our district.
speaker: karltutty

text: Oh, thank you. Second question is, it's not accompanied by any financials. There's a clause in there saying that, you know, an official agreement will need to be sorting out. What are you expecting in terms of some costs or is that going to be very, very difficult to ascertain?
speaker: grahamewebb

text: On the day-to-day stuff of a Waipā person crossing into Hamilton City or vice versa, I don't expect there would be any costs coming out of that. It's simply business as usual work. It's just giving us the flexibility to not be so caught up in the boundary issue. If it's a longer term agreement,  due, you know, perhaps to a civil defence emergency or something like that, we would need to negotiate those terms at the time. And that will be part of the contractual arrangement that we negotiate that in advance where possible.
speaker: karltutty

text: Yeah, my point of asking that, of course, is if you happen to go and do a job that requires the officers to go into that Hamilton area, of course, it takes them away from doing, you know, their routine jobs and that's right, I think it needs some sort of fleshing out or some agreement to actually cover for that, that's all.
speaker: grahamewebb

text: Certainly, and we'll be having some clause in there that doesn't  provide an obligation, I guess you could say, in the sense that we will have some discretion about where and when that support is provided. We need to be able to maintain business as usual. Thanks, Carlton.
speaker: karltutty

text: Thanks, Graham. Lou, you had a question?
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: You think so, through you, the chair, to Carl. Carl, I just see it says to facilitate officer exchange to provide learning. Does this mean that we'll be having a regular exchange with the other districts, including Hamilton, and learning technologies from them or not?
speaker: loubrown

text: That's something we hope to develop. The Animal Control Officers have got a very active Animal Control Officers Institute. So there's already quite a forum going on of officers meeting together on a regular basis and sharing their knowledge and understanding. And there are some councils that are very sort of  considered to be subject matter experts in the Waikato when it comes to total control matters. So, we definitely see some efficiencies and some advantage to being able to actually move that into more of a practical sense. So, rather than just sitting around a table discussing these issues, they can actually go out in the field together and see how some of these things are applied. Thank you.
speaker: karltutty

text: Okay. Thanks, Lou. Everybody else alright for questions?
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Through you, Your Worship.  Yeah, I agree with Liz. Totally seems eminently practical and I'm happy to second the motion.
speaker: andrewbrown

text: Thanks, Andrew. So it's moved by Liz and seconded by Andrew. Was there any other discussion? Okay, I'll put the motion. All those in favour?
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Aye.

That said, the critical matters were certainly covered and they are set out there on page 27 of the agenda. text: OK. Any questions to Ken? No questions.  So I need a mover and seconder that they're a true and correct record. And that probably can only be Roger and Clare.

text: I'm happy to move.

text: Move Roger and seconded Clare. All those in favour. All right. I'm free. Carried. The next item on the agenda is the Local Government Funding Agency.  We all got that? Oh yeah. A bit of light reading before you go to bed. Light reading? Oh my goodness. Okay, Gary once again straight to Ken.
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Well, just a bit of context, Your Worship. The reason you've got the huge number of pages you've got is that you needed to see the documents before you agreed to signing them. So apologies for the extensive information there. Sarah is unfortunately ill today, so Ken will present the paper in her place.
speaker: garrydyet

text: Ken. Okay, yeah, thank you, Your Worship. So, yeah, so look, yeah, so what this does, and yes, my apologies as well for the size of the agenda, but obviously these are quite complex legal documents, and yeah, they did need to be published in full. But essentially what these are doing is giving effect to a whole bunch of changes, I suppose,  that were actually agreed to resolved at the LGFA's annual general meeting a year ago. So yeah, so look, it's pretty straightforward in that regard.  And I say these just give basis to that. The very key change that these things are giving effect to is the ability for council-controlled organisations, CCOs, to be actually able to access LGFA funding as well. The LGFA has been a very, very successful mechanism for local authority.  funding in terms of the costs of that funding being significantly reduced on what it would otherwise have been. Very, very effective in that regard. So just looking to extend that out to the CCOs. But what that has required is a number of changes to the relevant documentation.  I think it's important to point out, actually the report does point this out, is that Council has not had any specific legal advice in regard to these documents. What we are relying on is that two quite prestigious legal firms have both reviewed this documentation very, very thoroughly. Those two legal firms being Russell McVeigh on behalf of the LGFA,  They were instructed by the LGFA to redraft the documentation. And then Simpson-Greyson has effectively been the legal advice in regard to the councils. They've comprehensively reviewed the documentation on behalf of the Shareholders' Council, the Shareholders' Council representing the interests of the councils.  OK, so we have very much relied on that. Your Worship, I have had some questions overnight from Councillor St Pierre and in a conversation this morning before this meeting, I've been able to address those concerns to the Councillor's satisfaction. Apart from one, which I actually did have a very quick conversation with Simpson-Greyson this morning on,  And I did hope I'd get a response, and in fact I'm just checking the email on my phone right now. It doesn't look like that response has come through yet. But look, that one was a very, I guess, a relatively simple matter of the multi-issuer deed has removed the definition of a local authority.  And Councillor St Pierre's question was, you know, why have they removed the definition of a local authority from the multi-issuer deed? That definition actually still appears on the other two documents, but it's been removed from that one. So, like I say, I did ring Simpson Greaves in just about 15 minutes before this meeting commenced this morning, just asking them if they can explain that I haven't had a response back.  to date, but I would suggest—although, yeah, you're happy for Councillors here to comment, obviously—I would suggest that, you know, I would have thought that that was relatively minor in the scale of things as to why that definition has been removed. I'm sure it is for good reason, but I just can't give you that reason right now.  Okay, so with those things said, yeah, these are pretty complex legal documents. Yeah, but as I say, there has been very thorough legal review and they are giving effect to historic decisions.  What we are asking you today is for your approval of Council signing these, and the mechanism for the signing is two elected members, because these are deeds. We require two elected members to sign these a little later this week, because there is quite a tight deadline on these.  So, yes, we will be in contact subject to this resolution going through. We will be in contact with a couple of you in the next day or two to actually sign these documents as well. OK, thanks, Ken.
speaker: kenmorrisg

text: Clare, did you want to make any comment? Did you just have any concerns or did you just identify that that definition had been missed?
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Yeah, well, I thought it had been  deliberately taken out, actually, for a reason. But it was strange that it was removed there, but the other two deeds have still got it. And, of course, it really is because of that definition, you know, it sets the scene for who can actually participate. And if there was a broader definition of a local authority, whatever that might be, yeah, it would just mean that more people might say, well, I'm entitled to borrow this way as well. That's all. And I'm quite happy with the approach that Ken's taken. I said I'm quite happy to support  you know, the recommendation, but I just thought it was strange and he's been able to look into it. So that's great. Greg Morgan Thanks, Clare.
